title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 1
caption: Inverted follicular keratosis: lesion shows proliferative downgrowths of mature squamous epithelium with infundibular keratinization (H&E ×40).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 2
caption: Inverted follicular keratosis: higher magnification showing squamous eddies (H&E ×200).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 3
caption: Bowen disease: Shave biopsy specimen showing mainly papillomatous epidermal lesion with hyperkeratotic horn. Inset: closer view of the underlying lesional epidermis shows cells with nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and frequent and abnormal mitotic figures. (H&E, ×20; Inset: ×400).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 4
caption: Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia featuring acanthotic squamous epithelium showing irregular thick finger-like downgrowths into the underlying dermis. (H&E, ×20).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 5
caption: Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia: higher magnification view showing reactive-appearing squamous downgrowths with no significant cytologic atypia. The dermis shows mild chronic inflammation and granulation tissue formation (H&E, ×200).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 6
caption: Infundibulocystic hyperplasia: skin lesion showing follicular proliferative process with bland squamous cells and formation of dilated canals containing keratotic material. (H&E, ×40).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 7
caption: Infundibulocystic SCC: superficial areas showing infundibulocystic canals with deeper infiltrative squamous cell clusters featuring cellular atypia and mitoses (arrow). (H&E, ×100).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 8
caption: Verrucous hyperplasia: low power magnification view showing epidermal squamous proliferation with broad and superficial downgrowths of the epidermis. Overlying hyper-and parakeratosis is present. There is no atypia or koilocytes. (H&E, ×100).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 9
caption: Eccrine squamous syringometaplasia: bland appearing squamous islands in the dermis centered around eccrine lumina. Scattered lymphocytes are present in the surrounding dermis. (H&E, ×200).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 10
caption: Desmoplastic trichoepithelioma: macroscopic picture showing an ulcerative nodular lesion with raised rolled edges features which mimic SCC or BCC.

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 11
caption: Desmoplastic trichoepithelioma: low power magnification showing hyperplastic downgrowths of epidermis with cords of basaloid tumor cells arranged in a pseudoinfiltrative pattern. (H&E, ×40).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 12
caption: Meningioma: medium power magnification showing syncytial sheets and whorls of tumor cells with bland nuclear features. The presence of nuclear pseudoinclusions, psammoma bodies and the absence of atypia allow the distinction from SCC. (H&E, ×200).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 13
caption: Endometriosis with decidualization: medium power magnification showing cystic space surrounded by large polygonal cells with basophilic cytoplasm and bland nuclei. The cyst wall is rimmed by a layer of endometrial cells (arrow). (H&E, ×200).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 14
caption: Keratoacanthoma: clinical photograph showing a well-circumscribed reddish nodule with erosion on the surface.

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 15
caption: Keratoacanthoma: low power magnification showing a crateriform lesion which is filled with central keratinous plug and bounded by proliferative lesional squamous epithelium. (H&E, ×20).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 16
caption: Keratoacanthoma-like SCC: low power magnification showing a crateriform lesion with infiltrative islands and clusters of squamous cells at the base (arrow). (H&E, ×20).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 17
caption: Proliferating tricholemmal tumor: macroscopic photograph showing a circumscribed cutaneous reddish-pink nodular tumor with surface erosions.

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 18
caption: Proliferating tricholemmal tumor: the lesion shows proliferation of squamous cells with clear cytoplasm and abrupt pilar-type keratinization (arrow) (H&E, ×200).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 19
caption: Clinical photograph showing a red, scaly plaque on the skin surface. The patient just had a biopsy performed with sutures still in place.

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 20
caption: Bowen disease: medium-power magnification showing skin with full thickness epidermal dysplasia which is characterized by loss of the nuclear polarity, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitoses at all levels. The undulating deep epidermal contour and presence of eccrine ducts that have been colonized by the tumor cells (arrow) can potentially mimic invasion. (H&E, ×200).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 21
caption: Basal cell carcinoma: (a) low power magnification showing infiltrative irregular islands of basaloid tumor cells which appear to have more ample eosinophilic cytoplasm mimicking the appearance of SCC (H&E, ×100). (b) Tumor cells are diffusely positive for Ber-EP4. (c) Tumor cells also show diffuse positivity for bcl-2.

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 22
caption: Keratotic BCC: medium-power magnification showing solid growth of tumor cells with foci of squamous differentiation featuring keratin pearls (arrow). Focal tumour-stromal cleft formation with myxoid substance is seen on the right. (H&E, ×200).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 23
caption: Spindle cell melanoma: medium-power magnification showing dermal pleomorphic spindle cell proliferation and focal junctional melanocytic nest (arrow). (H&E, ×100).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 24
caption: Metastatic SCC: low-power magnification showing solid growth of SCC which is predominantly located in the dermis and subcutaneous tissue. The overlying epidermis appears normal. This should raise suspicion of a metastatic deposit. (H&E, ×40).

title: Simulators of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin: diagnostic challenges on small biopsies and clinicopathological correlation.
label: Figure 25
caption: Cutaneous anaplastic large cell lymphoma: low-power magnification showing hyperplastic squamous islands (arrow) associated proliferation of large neoplastic lymphocytes. (H&E, ×100).

title: Pigmented tumor in the nostril.
label: Figure 1.
caption: Exophytic, corneal brown lesion located in the left nostril.

title: Pigmented tumor in the nostril.
label: Figure 2.
caption: A: Epithelial proliferation both above and below the level of residual epidermis (hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain); B: Keratin crypt formation at the surface of the lesion with hyperkeratotic epithelium and acanthosis (H&E stain); C: Epithelial proliferation containing a squamous eddy formation (H&E stain); D: High-power photomicrograph depicting base of inverted follicular keratosis with peripheral palisading of basaloid cells at the periphery of the tumor lobules and intercellular edema; E: Squamous eddy formation.

title: Pigmented tumor in the nostril.
label: Figure 3.
caption: Spontaneous regression of the inverted follicular keratosis

title: Human Papillomavirus Deoxyribonucleic Acid may not be Detected in Non-genital Benign Papillomatous Skin Lesions by Polymerase Chain Reaction.
label: Figure 1
caption: Gel electrophoresis (7 is the positive control, 8 is a negative control, 6 is the block of 88-775 (wart) 1,5,9 are seborrheic keratosis (negative result), 2,10,11 are nevus sebaceous (negative result), 3,4 are inverted follicular keratosis (negative result), 12 is trichilemmoma (negative result))

title: Human Papillomavirus Deoxyribonucleic Acid may not be Detected in Non-genital Benign Papillomatous Skin Lesions by Polymerase Chain Reaction.
label: Figure 2
caption: Gel electrophoresis (1 is a negative control, 2 is a positive control, 3,4,10 are inverted follicular keratosis negative result, 5,6,7,13 are seborrheic keratosis (negative result), 8,11,12 are nevus sebaceous (negative result) 9 is trichilemmoma (negative result))

title: Inverted follicular keratosis of the lip.
label: Figure 1
caption: Pedunculated nodule, 8-12 mm in diameter, with a keratotic surface, in the upper lip midline skin

title: Rare case of external dental fistula of the submental region misdiagnosed as inverted follicular keratosis and thyroglossal duct cyst.
label: Fig. 1
caption: Pre-operative MRI revealed a well-demarcated cyst close to the hyoid bone. High signal intensity was found at the partial center in T1-weighted image and entirely at T2-weighted image. This was filmed using short TI inversion recovery imaging.

title: Rare case of external dental fistula of the submental region misdiagnosed as inverted follicular keratosis and thyroglossal duct cyst.
label: Fig. 2
caption: Cystic structure or thyroid gland follicle, mucus component were not histopathologically detected, and inflammatory cells were mostly occupied; the latter resection sample is more scarred than the former. (Hematoxylin and eosin staining, 1.25× original magnification).

title: Rare case of external dental fistula of the submental region misdiagnosed as inverted follicular keratosis and thyroglossal duct cyst.
label: Fig. 3
caption: Extraorally, approximately 10 mm suture was dehiscent at the submental region, and gentle pressure on the surrounding tissue produced suppurative drainage from the central punctum.

title: Rare case of external dental fistula of the submental region misdiagnosed as inverted follicular keratosis and thyroglossal duct cyst.
label: Fig. 4
caption: Periapical radiograph examination indicated 6 mm × 7 mm radiolucency at the apex of the left mandibular second molar.

title: Rare case of external dental fistula of the submental region misdiagnosed as inverted follicular keratosis and thyroglossal duct cyst.
label: Fig. 5
caption: Fistulography confirmed that the cutaneous lesion communicated with the periapex of the left mandibular molars.

title: Rare case of external dental fistula of the submental region misdiagnosed as inverted follicular keratosis and thyroglossal duct cyst.
label: Fig. 6
caption: The use of a sonde revealed that the tract was leading from the submental lesion to the apex of the left mandibular second molar.

title: Giant Squamous Cell Papilloma of the Eyelid-Diagnostic and Therapeutic Challenges.
label: Figure 1
caption: Giant squamous cell papilloma involving the left lower eyelid (a) and (b).

title: Giant Squamous Cell Papilloma of the Eyelid-Diagnostic and Therapeutic Challenges.
label: Figure 2
caption: Clinical appearance of the left lower eyelid 1 week (a) and (b) and 2 months (c) and (d) after tumor removal and surgical reconstruction of the excised area.

title: Giant Squamous Cell Papilloma of the Eyelid-Diagnostic and Therapeutic Challenges.
label: Figure 3
caption: Histopathological features. (a) Hyperkeratotic epidermis and endophytic epithelial growth into the dermis with squamous pearl (arrow). There is only mild cytological atypia with intact basement membrane and no increased mitotic activity indicative of the benign nature of the lesion (inset). (b) Diffuse p16 immunopositivity both in the nucleus and in the cytoplasm (see inset) confirms HPV infection. Note the immunonegativity in the adjacent epidermis. (a: Haematoxylin & Eosin, original magnification: x20; inset: x300; b: Immunohistochemistry with DAB chromogen, using monoclonal antibody (clone MX007, Master Diagnostica; x20; inset: x300).

title: Two Distinct Lesions of Inverted Follicular Keratosis of the Scalp: A Case Report.
label: Figure 1
caption: The first lesion, a skin-colored pedunculated mass (1 cm) with a smooth-regular surface and minimal crusting

title: Two Distinct Lesions of Inverted Follicular Keratosis of the Scalp: A Case Report.
label: Figure 2
caption: The second lesion, a skin-colored papule (0.3 cm × 0.4 cm) with a verrucous surface (red arrow)

title: Two Distinct Lesions of Inverted Follicular Keratosis of the Scalp: A Case Report.
label: Figure 3
caption: Photomicrograph of the first lesion showed skin tissue with squamous cell proliferation that forms distinct nests with endophytic growth toward the dermis (yellow arrow) and horn cysts (red arrow) (H&E, 40X)H&E: Hematoxylin and eosin.

title: Two Distinct Lesions of Inverted Follicular Keratosis of the Scalp: A Case Report.
label: Figure 4
caption: Photomicrograph of the first lesion showing concentric circles of keratin (red arrow) with squamous eddies (yellow arrows) (H&E, 100X)H&E: Hematoxylin and eosin.

title: Two Distinct Lesions of Inverted Follicular Keratosis of the Scalp: A Case Report.
label: Figure 5
caption: Photomicrograph of the second lesion showing skin tissue with stratified bulbous squamous cell proliferation (yellow arrows) and hyperkeratotic foci (red arrow) (H&E, 40X)H&E: Hematoxylin and eosin.

title: Two Distinct Lesions of Inverted Follicular Keratosis of the Scalp: A Case Report.
label: Figure 6
caption: Photomicrograph of the second lesion showing horn cysts (red arrow) and concentric circles of keratin with squamous eddies (yellow arrow) (H&E, 100X)H&E: Hematoxylin and eosin.

title: Two Distinct Lesions of Inverted Follicular Keratosis of the Scalp: A Case Report.
label: Figure 7
caption: Immunohistochemistry with anti-Ki67 antibody showed low expression of Ki-67 proliferation index for the first lesion (anti-Ki-67 antibody IHC, 40X)Ki-67: Kiel-67; IHC: Immunohistochemistry.

title: Two Distinct Lesions of Inverted Follicular Keratosis of the Scalp: A Case Report.
label: Figure 8
caption: Immunohistochemistry with anti-Ki67 antibody showed low expression of Ki-67 proliferation index for the second lesion (anti-Ki-67 antibody IHC, 40X)IHC: Immunohistochemistry; Ki-67: Kiel-67.

title: Inverted Follicular Keratosis: A Retrospective Study Over 10 Years.

caption: Clinical features of inverted follicular keratosis (a) affecting the cheek with keratotic centre, (b) affecting the scalp, (c) hyperpigmented lesion affecting the arm, (d) hypopigmented form affecting the cheek

title: Inverted Follicular Keratosis: A Retrospective Study Over 10 Years.
label: Figure 2
caption: Histopathological features: low power view showing endophytic intradermal proliferation of basaloid cells with a variable degree of squamoid differentiation (HEx25)

title: Inverted Follicular Keratosis: A Retrospective Study Over 10 Years.
label: Figure 3
caption: Inverted seborrheic keratosis: (a) intradermal proliferation of close-set basaloid cells organized in an endophytic configuration (HEx50). (b) Presence of pseudohorn cysts (→) (HEx100). (c) high power of pseudohorn cysts (→) and squamous eddies () (HEx100). (d) The dermis shows severe chronic inflammation (HEx100)

title: Inverted Follicular Keratosis Presenting as a Cutaneous Horn.
label: Figure 1
caption: Photograph shows a single, well-defined, hyperkeratotic, hyper-pigmented, conical outgrowth (0.5 cm × 1 cm) with scaling and hemorrhagic crusting on the surface

title: Inverted Follicular Keratosis Presenting as a Cutaneous Horn.
label: Figure 2
caption: Photomicrograph of skin biopsy specimen showing an endophytic tumour comprising of lobules of squamous cells and peripheral basaloid cells (H & E, 100x)

title: Inverted Follicular Keratosis Presenting as a Cutaneous Horn.
label: Figure 3
caption: Photomicrograph showing numerous squamous eddies (H & E, 400x)

title: Cornu Cutaneum: Case Reports of Patients With a Cutaneous Horn Associated With Either a Verruca Vulgaris or an Inverted Follicular Keratosis and a Review of the Etiologies of Cutaneous Horns.
